content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "SHORTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Tests coverage is good and instructions are clear enougth. I would have preferred ouput a name than the index base of the last runner but it's just a matter of preference so I approve anyway.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This puzzle is interesting, is not very easy, but also is not very hard, has full test cases

u can make first case more understandable for example 

input  | output
3             2 52  
0 2                
1 2 
2 2
 and maybe u can give 2 example if u want to make it more understandable 
input | output
3            -1 101
1 1
1 1
I'm less of a fan of considering 0 speed. In particular it's not clear what time should be returned if only one person has 0 speed.

Good idea, here are some suggestions:
I would not ask for time elapsed since the race began. I think it brings confusion / complexifies the output.
Instead of asking index of the person, I would add a name to each input and ask for name.

it is interesting to ask for the last person, it is trickly but perfectly clear though.

The puzzle is nice for a CoC. However, the statement seems bizarrely long and thus confusing. Shouldn't it just be:

"Goal: There are [[N]] runners in a race who start at different times [[T]] and run at different speeds [[S]. Determine which runner passes the 100m line last."

The output is also confusing, but it's unfortunately much more difficult to clarify. The best I could do was to add some extra whitespace and to be careful about sentence syntax (which matters a lot). The most important addition is mentioning that the runners are 0-indexed.

"<<Line 1:>> Two space separated integers [[I]] and [[F]].
[[I]] is the index (0-based) of the last person to cross the 100m line, or {{-1}} if more than one person crosses last or nobody crosses at all.
[[F]] is the time in seconds since the race began that the last person crosses the 100m line, rounded up, or {{0}} if nobody crosses."

Other notes:
* I notice that your code uses a ceil() for elapsed time before comparing to the longest time, which is error-prone. It would mean that two runners that start at the same time but run at 15 and 16 m/s would both pass the 100m line "at the same time."
* Speaking of which, who runs at 15 m/s???

A good puzzle. I think the statement could be a bit clearer about what is being asked (index and time passed since beginning) and what units are used. Also you're using the same letter T for both the time they start and the time they finish. A few longer test cases wouldn't hurt. I would consider allowing runners with 0 speed to throw a bit of a curve ball at the solvers :)
Like qsantos said, not fit for reverse, and should be called a race, not a marathon
Maybe clarify that the times should be rounded up. It feels a bit harsh for a reverse mode too.
A marathon is a race of 26.2 miles (roughly 42km). I'm confused as to why there would be a line at 100m. I think it would be better to call it "a race" or "a 100m race" instead of "a marathon"
I Added some new test cases using a script i wrote and changed some descriptions

It may be useful to add zero speed in example 
input  | output
3             2 52  
0 2                
1 2 
9 0
2 2
